Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: metabolic engineering of terpenoid indole alkaloids using transcriptional regulators in C. roseus hairy roots

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1066879/1064903 Shanks/Gibson

Plants produce large numbers of chemicals that are useful as drugs for treating a variety of medical conditions. Unfortunately, these chemicals are often produced by plants in only trace amounts. As a result, large quantities of plant material must often be used to produce small amounts of drugs, making these drugs very expensive. An example of this problem is provided by a class of compounds produced by Catharanthus roseus (periwinkle), known as terpenoid indole alkaloids. Terpenoid indole alkaloids include chemicals such as vincristine and vinblastine, which are used to treat certain types of cancer, and ajmalicine, which is used to treat hypertension. As periwinkle produces these chemicals in only trace amounts, they can cost over one million dollars per pound. To reduce the costs of these drugs, it is critical to develop varieties of periwinkle that produce these drugs in higher amounts. Towards that end, the effects of increasing expression of the biosynthetic genes that are responsible for production of these drugs will be investigated. A two-fold strategy for increasing expression of these biosynthetic genes will be pursued. Part one of this strategy is to test the effects of reducing expression of repressor genes that decrease expression of the biosynthetic genes. Part two of this strategy is to decrease expression of the repressor genes while simultaneously increasing expression of activator genes that increase expression of the biosynthetic genes. The hypothesis being tested is that, by decreasing expression of repressors and increasing expression of activators, it should be possible to achieve a significant increase in expression of the biosynthetic genes. This increase in expression of the biosynthetic genes should then lead to increased production of terpenoid indole alkaloids, allowing those terpenoid indole alkaloids that are useful as drugs to be produced at a lower cost. Previously uncharacterized chemicals that accumulate in response to alterations in expression of the biosynthetic genes will also be analyzed. Characterization of these chemicals will both provide valuable information regarding the biochemical pathways by which terpenoid indole alkaloids are produced, as well as potentially providing information regarding additional chemicals that may be tested for use as drugs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant-derived natural products play a large role in the pharmaceutical industry, either as novel lead compounds or directly as drugs. Unfortunately these plant pharmaceuticals are often very expensive, as they are synthesized in plants in very low levels and chemical synthesis or production in microorganisms has often been infeasible. The terpenoid indole alkaloids (TIAs) are prime examples and include several valuable pharmaceuticals, most notably the anticancer drugs vinblastine (Velbe®) and vincristine (Oncovin®). The overall goal of this project was to characterize how production of TIAs is regulated. This knowledge will improve our understanding of the regulation of plant metabolism, particularly secondary metabolism. In addition, this knowledge is necessary for future efforts to successfully engineer TIA and related pathways to increase production of secondary metabolites, thereby decreasing the costs of important plant-derived pharmaceuticals.

 

Production of TIAs is regulated by TIA transcriptional activators that increase the activity of key TIA biosynthetic genes and by TIA transcriptional repressors that decrease the activity of key TIA biosynthetic genes. Previous efforts to increase production of TIAs by increasing the expression of the TIA transcriptional activator genes altered the activities of a number of TIA biosynthetic genes, but had only modest effects on TIA metabolite levels. Thus, the focus of this study was on testing the effects of decreasing the expression of TIA transcriptional repressor genes. Several transgenic periwinkle hairy root lines with decreased expression of different combinations of five TIA transcriptional repressor genes were generated. Characterization of these lines revealed that they have significantly decreased activity levels of the TIA transcriptional repressor genes after induction of an RNAi construct. These transgenic lines also exhibited altered expression of several TIA regulatory and biosynthetic genes. However, surprisingly, in most cases the expression levels of these genes were lower in the transgenic lines grown under conditions where expression of the TIA repressor genes was decreased. This is in contrast to the expectation that decreasing expression of the TIA repressor genes would result in increased expression of some TIA regulatory and biosynthetic genes. These results illustrate the need for a more comprehensive analysis of the regulation of TIA pathways. These analyses would both improve our basic understanding of the regulation of these metabolic pathways and enable scientists to design improved methods to increase production of TIAs in plants, thereby lowering the costs of TIA pharmaceuticals.
